ratings.comment: Joan is wonderful. Good lecturer, good OH. All content is delivered in lectures which are unrecorded, so don't get sick.

Joan is amazing. 100% take rmi 300 with her. I am not a business school student and she found a way to make this class fun and interesting when i absolutely am not interested in insurance but she was so sweet and funny too!

Joan is an awesome professor who sincerely cares about her students. Joan makes the lectures engaging, dynamic, and has lots of office hours for extra help. Her exams are straightforward and based on the lectures. All in all, TAKE JOAN!! She is an excellent professor, the topic is useful for all majors, and the class material is interesting!

i took this as an elective-wish i didnt. I showed up to every class and understood everything (or so i thought), I always got the lecture questions correct and 100s on every quiz and homework. But the exams were so hard and impossible to finish without bsing a few answers. Joan is fine, but i was expecting better bc of her ratings

Never gave a clear definition to a single vocab word. online exams were horrible, as we were given 75 mins for 15 short answer questions, so 5 min per question, but needed 3 mins to read and understand the question. Instead of giving answers to questions, TA and prof would respond with "we talked about this in lecture #14". Slides contained no info

"specific definitions are not important as long as you listen to what we talk about in class" Never posts slides. I never wanted to ask questions because she made me feel dumb when I didn't understand. Information in lectures made sense, but the exams were crazy hard... all short answer with multiple parts.. almost never finished.

Joan is a fine professor, and RMI 300 is a relevant and useful class to take as an elective. Her lecture style, though, is rough. She is passionate and gives lots of examples but Every. Single. Word. She. Says. will be on the exam. Instead of taking notes traditionally, just type everything she says. Even comments that seem off topic.

I truly loved RMI 300. I took it entirely online and it was run very well. Joan is the best professor I have ever had at UW. She is caring, compassionate, inspiring, and so much more. She has inspired me to double major in RMI and I could not be more happy. If you are looking for a genuinely enjoyable and relatively easy breath course this is it!
Wonderful Professor, super caring. Joan really cares about her students

Joan was a fairly good professor. You can tell she is really sweet. Lectures were semi interesting, and she would have students volunteer to help answer questions. Was annoying when same kids would constantly volunteer. Discussion was mandatory, but always easy and only 50 mins. Grade consists mostly of midterms and final exam.
Joan is great.

Amazing professor and clearly cares about student's learning. Extremely good at teaching. Manages to get to know a lot of students in a huge lecture and is extremely kind. She can also figure out if you understand content and are studying hard. She says she tries not to trick, but her mc tests are really hard and confusingly worded even if u study.

Joan is a true gem. She cares about her students' understanding. She will send you emails if she is concerned that you individually do not understand something, out of a 200 person lecture. Joan is sweet. Her exams are weird at times, but extremely doable to do well, provided that you study. Joan, and her class are well worth it

Joan is a great teacher! She holds a lot of office hours to help explain difficult material. You must go to lecture if you expect to do well in this class as the posted handouts are incomplete for studying. Definitely would recommend the discussion section grade for this class. An easy 5% based off of 2 quizzes, a few homeworks, and in class work.

Joan is terrific person but her lectures can get really boring. If you understand basic business concepts, this class is a cake walk. Highly recommend taking her class while you're still an underclassman.

Joan is lovely in every way, her lectures are engaging and very interesting. I really had no idea what RMI was when I began the course and at the end of it I am totally hooked on it! I would suggest not taking the TA section for credit to give yourself some more flexibility. Her exams are fair so it is not that scary to be solely graded on them.

Joan is awesome. She gives you note sheets to follow along in lecture and you cover a lot of different topics relating to RMI. She really wants students to succeed and will do anything to help her students.

The course grading breakdown relies purely on exams. Quoting syllabus, "If you choose not to include TA section, exams will be apportioned as: lower mid-term 28%, higher 37%; final 35%.If include TA section in your grade, apportionment is: TA section: 5%; Lower mid-term 26%, higher 34%; final 35%." Test materials often difficult and obscure.

Gives really helpful note sheets at every lecture, but you have to make sure that you attend class. Study with a buddy, and you will pass her class. She is an amazing teacher who really cares about her students.

Going into the class I had no clue really what risk management was. RMI 300 is the most applicable subject I have ever taken. Since taking the class and having Joan as my teacher I have switched my major from Finance to RMI. She isn't crazy hard but expects participation from students.

Joan is one of the best professors I have had at UW-Madison. She clearly cares about her students, and it shows when she learns tens if not hundreds of their names. She gives interesting lectures and valuable lessons. The class is not too difficult with three tests making up the entirety of the grade.

Joan is a fantastic professor. Like everyone else says, she truly cares about every student and their success. She does throw your questions back at you, but in a way that gets you to think and better understand the material, yourself. She will help if you still don't understand. Wish I could take the class again.

Joan Schmit is the type of professor that makes going to class fun and engaging. She takes the time to get to know most, if not all, of her students. And she makes a point to encourage her students to reflect on their learning, rather than just asking them to memorize material. Joan is one of the most caring professors I've had here at UW. 12/10rec

Joan is one of my favorite professors of all time! This class has extremely valuable information for business and personal use. Joan cares so much about every student's success and she will help you figure out the answers yourself so you actually learn. I can't emphasize enough how valuable this class is and how awesome Joan is!

Joan is excellent at making the class engaging and interesting. She tries very hard to use content that is applicable to many career fields. She also provides outlines that make note-taking much easier. She is very particular about what answers she is looking for so that may be a challenge for some students.

Joan likes to give out an outline in lecture, is a very engaging lecturer and a very nice person. Yet, she rarely gives a clear-cut definition (besides "risk") and often relies on a map of examples to finally explain her point. She is often unclear. She doesn't really make time to hear your exam appeal, instead telling you to "think about it"...

Joan was easily my favorite professors ever. Her lectures were very intriguing and always interesting.  The only way to do well is to go to lecture! Also, discussions are extremely beneficial, especially to those who were confused in her lecture about something. Joan also gets to know people personally even tho it is a huge class; she cares a lot.

This class clicks for some students and is super hard for others. For me it was super hard. Things didn't click until the final for me. I usually depend on a textbook but there isnt one in this class. Getting a good grade basically requires a lot of office hours.

I have no idea how Joan doesn't have a 5 on here. She puts in more effort than any other professor I've had and it's clear she wants all of her students to succeed. She knows about 25-50% of the students names in an enormous lecture, you'll never find this level of support in another course.

Wonderful professor, answers questions clearly and respectfully, makes herself available to students who need extra help. Her lectures are set up nice and she gives you an outline for each one to help you learn, you fill it in yourself so make sure to go to class. Very nice, explains topics thoroughly and clearly!
Very easy grader. Very nice lectures. Very nice person( a very nice professor encountered). If you complain about Joan I might wonder what sort of class you could feel comfortable

Joan Schmit was easily my favorite professor in the business school (and I'm a senior). She is enthusiastic with every topic she teaches. She genuinely cares that we learn. She's also brilliant and has very published in this field.

Joan is the most phenomenal human being you will have the honor of meeting. By far the best professor at UW. Definitely not an easy course; however, it's because she genuinely cares about her students' comprehension of the material instead of memorization. You won't regret it, LOVE JOAN!
Horrible

Joan is a phenomenal professor and really cares about her students. She is more than willing to help in office hours and since some of the material can be challenging, I would recommend going to them! She is so great, by far my favorite professor at Madison. Her excitement for the material makes the class even more enjoyable.

She is a good person, but not good at teaching. She is unclear about many things, and the way she wording the questions is so weird. Understanding the materials has nothing to do with having good grade. She often throws back the question you have and let you figure out by yourself. If I can figure out myself, what is the purpose having you there.

Favorite professor on campus. Loved going to lecture and is encouraged because notes are not posted anywhere except for an outline. Business students looking for a class outside their major, TAKE IT. Material is interesting and easy to understand but test questions can be difficult so it is a hard A but very doable to get a B. Minimal course load.

It boggles my mind that Joan doesn't have a perfect 5.0.  You will NEVER find a more helpful, clear, and kind professor.  Everything you could want from a professor/class.  A fantastic breadth class for anyone but even moreso any business student.

If you are considering taking RMI 300 for an easy A, you might be surprised... Joan, though, will make it her life's mission over the course of the semester to make sure you COMPREHEND the material. She is the sweetest little woman and DEEPLY cares about her students. This class will change you for the better if you let it. Also, the TAs are great!

Joan is a truly amazing person,  an absolute saint and one of the best people on this campus, not just of professors - anyone. The class material is really not that hard, but the multiple choice questions on the exams are brutally difficult. She is very willing to help, but I got a terrible grade even though I went everyday and understood material.

The only reason this class is easy is because of Joan's phenomenal teaching. The material is difficult, but Joan makes it easy. If you go to class, pay attention, and study before the exams; you should have no problem doing well. If you're considering taking this class as an elective, do it. Joan is great and the class is very interesting.

Joan is amazing and even takes the time to learn most students' names. I didn't take the discussions for a grade and got an A. Just go to the lectures, take solid notes, and attend her review sessions and it isn't difficult to do well. Don't buy the textbook.  This is a really interesting and rewarding class.  I would recommend it for a  breadth

Her exams did not do a good job in showing how much I learned in this class. The material is easy to understand, but the way she words her exams, makes the class very difficult (grade wise).   3 exams. No textbook. Discussion optional. You have to go to lecture, otherwise it will be difficult to pass. If you are considering as breadth, don't take

Joan is an AMAZING professor. She really cares about her students. One thing to just know about this class though is that material seems very easy to grasp in class, however go to office hours with Joan and she will show you how to apply it in real life. Applying the material is what the exams test, so go to see her it's well worth your time.

Joan is awesome... She's extremely invested in her students and would love to see each of them succeed. I personally didn't know much about Risk Management & Insurance entering the course, but she really captured my interest in it. Tests are fair but not easy. I attended almost every lecture and will most likely finish with a B.

Words cannot begin to describe how invested Joan is in her student's success. She will do whatever it takes to make sure you succeed. If you want a class that takes no work to get an A, this class isn't for you and this school isn't for you. If you want to put the time in (1 hr outside classweek) you will learn more than you could have imagined.

Joan is the 2nd best professor I've had in my 2.5 years at Madison. She's one of the very few teachers that actually care, and you can tell from her lectures. She really enjoys teaching and the material she teaches. Be sure to go to class, since there is no required book to supplement the lectures. A+!

Didn't feel like I was getting help I needed. Had to figure out stuff I was confused on on my own because she doesn't answer your question well if you ask her or she makes you ask it in front of 250 people and try to make you figure it out. Tests are tough, the material would be good to know but she rambles on about concepts that SHOULD be easy.

I liked Joan as a person, but if you're lost on concepts, GOOD LUCK getting help. She has many available office hours but if you ask her a question, she will throw it right back at you and make you feel uncomfortable if you have no idea.  I've gone into her office hours and felt very unwelcome and uneasy.  She can be very confusing in lectures, too
Joan is by far my favorite professor so far. Her lectures are so simple, but I still learn a lot. She's very nice and is very good at helping you understand if you need help.

Joan Schmit is a saint. It's hard not to fall in love with her if you have her as a professor. She is engaging, clear, and is heavily invested in making sure you enjoy the material and do well. By far one of the best professors I've ever had. If you're even considering taking her, don't give it a second thought. She is awesome.

Joan is obviously a bright professor and is extremely open to helping you with understanding the material. The problem is that her test are totally absurd. As another review here as mentioned, you could understand everything about the material and still get a lot of questions wrong simply on the basis that the questions are so confusing!

Joan is the best!  Shes fun and approachable, and really wants you to succeed.  She learned about half of our lectures 100 regular attendees by the end of the semester.  Homework is minimal and easy.  Easy B, but hard A because of the application questions on the exams.
Joan is a GREAT person, super helpful and approachable

Joan makes class interesting and really cares about her students. She is always available for extra clarification or help outside of class. Discussion is optional but I recommend having Kenny as a TA. Overall a really great class.

Joan is great. She truly cares about her students and is available outside of class to help with anything. She actually learned most of the students names in a 150 person lecture. The exams are fair. I would recommend discussion section with Kenny.

Joan is very passionate about the material and willing to help you learn but she writes ridiculous M.C. questions for her exams with no curve.  Very informative class with optional discussion. Just confusing exams to the point where you could know all the material in the question and still have no idea what the answer is.
